Mine is the lighting on people's faces in their helmets!
Gah, drives me crazy. I get it...it's a movie and we need to see the actor's faces....but seeing the *inside* of someone's helmet lit up like car headlights just breaks my immersion immediately. How do they even see outside the helmet, the inside is lit up so much! (example would be how hard it is to see outside your car if the dome light is on while you're driving)
Very rarely, a movie gets this right, and the inside of the helmet is dark or very modestly lit.
Bonus non-subject pet peeve: When it's dark....shining flashlights in people's faces as they deliver their line in any movie whatsoever. No one would put up with that in real life. Especially the movies where the actor just keeps their eyes wide open as they speak with a flashlight on their face. Ummm, no. You'd be "Get that out of my face!"

I always wondered, since I have always said "I feel like a million bucks!" whenever I feel great...
Do billionaires say that when they are feeling super bad?

It would take them nearly 32 thousand years to count to a trillion, if they said one number every second without a break.
Heck, even to count to just 1 billion with that same method, it would take nearly 32 years.
Factoring one third of your life sleeping and one third of your life doing other things, if you counted for 8 hours a day, it would take you nearly 96 years to count to a billion in that way.
So, pretty safe to say you'll never say all the numbers to a billion, much less a trillion.

This is an absolutely horrible question to ask, and I can guarantee you won't get the job.
Source: I'm HR, and sit in on dozens of interviews a week.
You might think this is a clever question to ask, and it might be, but the interview panel looks at this question as you bullying them. It's a VERY passive-aggressive way of putting the panel on the spot and basically saying "Tell me right now why you're not going to hire me...and if you don't have an answer, I've obviously got the job already"
We get this question once or twice a week from a candidate...and every single time we get it, the interview panel (always different people) takes tremendous umbrage with it. The discussions after the interviews ALWAYS include how that specific follow-up question really put them off the candidate.
It's not a good idea, just don't do it.
A MUCH better alternative would be to confident statement as to how you think that you would be a perfect fit for the position, and that you think you fulfill all the qualifications, and leave it at that. But don't put the panel on-the-spot by asking for interview feedback during the interview like that.

I would want the power to know where anything is, just by concentrating on it.
This could be as mundane as "Where is Mike's remote control right now."...oh, it's behind his dresser.
...or as profitable as "Where is the closest cache of unclaimed cash of least $50 to me?"...oh, there's an altoids tin of $80 buried 2 feet underground a few blocks over.

WRITING.TITLE: What obscure not common Super Power would you want the most?

WRITING.TEXT: Oh sure, no argument here, always go to court.
What an amazing picture.

This is completely false. Any traffic cop that is issuing tickets has 1 or 2 days set aside in their schedule per month to simply attend court for the tickets they have written.
You think the date that you are assigned to show up in court from the ticket you got is random? Nope...that's the date that the cop already has scheduled to be in court already.
Granted, the cop MAY miss the day in court due to something unforeseen (like being sick, or a family emergency)...but the odds of that are of course very low.
Rest assured, the cop will be in court on the same day you are.

I think that my confusion lie in the way he stated it.
If he'd said "The Air Force is the smallest it's been during it's entire existence."...that would make sense and be instantly understandable.
But the way he said it, by saying it's the smallest it's been since 1947...really makes it sound like he (or whomever gave him the information) looked at a graph and saw only lower numbers prior to 1947...not realizing that the AF wasn't even established then.

See, that makes a ton of sense to me.
Even when the pres talked about the Navy not having this few of ships since WWI....Ummm, you mean when we were pumping them out of the shipyards as fast as the rivets could cool down, because we were having ships sunk DAILY?
That was an Age of Attrition. You counted engagements in terms of tons of steel sunk. I mean, my god, TON OF STEEL sunk. It was purely attrition.
A single (prepared) ship from today's era could probably destroy an entire fleet from the WWII days...all without the enemy fleet even knowing where the ship was.
Technology and advancements mean that Numbers such that the President fear-mongers upon are not as relevant a metric as they once were.

WRITING.TITLE: ELI5: The U.S. President just said in his Weekly Address that the U.S. Air Force is the smallest it's been since 1947. How is that possible since the AF was established in 1947?
